Coding/direnv.title: direnv
Coding/direnv.content:
direnv lets you define environment variables to be loaded only within certain directories. It‚Äôs a great way to save secret variables that are project-specific, without cluttering your global shell config.
Installation
brew install direnv
echo 'eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"' >> ~/.zshrc

Usage
echo 'export SECRET_TOKEN="super-secret"' > .envrc
echo 'export API_KEY="12345"' >> .envrc
direnv allow

Whenever you cd into this folder, the environment variables will load.
Don‚Äôt commit the secrets!
Add to .gitignore:
.envrc

Games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Duplicating-c.title: Duplicating cards effectively
Games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Duplicating-c.content:
A lot of characters benefit greatly from having a key card duplicated as many times as possible. One time is good, but two times (or even more?) is fantastic.
Remove other Epiphany cards
Each Copy Card event in Chaos randomly selects 3 cards, of which you choose 1 to copy. If you want your target card to appear as one of the choices, one strategy is to remove as many alternatives as possible.
Instead of removing basic cards right away, you can instead remove other characters‚Äô unique cards. By sacrificing their deck‚Äôs strength, you can build one deck to be especially strong.
This is easier to pull off after your characters have developed a fair amount, as survival becomes less of an issue.
Unique cards
Some characters have cards with the Unique attribute, which means they can‚Äôt be copied. Some cards gain Unique from Epiphanies. Since Unique cards will not be chosen as Copy targets, you don‚Äôt need to remove them in preparation for Copy events.
Pairing characters with these cards will make it a little bit easier to copy the card you are targeting.
The first boss is key
It‚Äôs much easier to duplicate your target cards at the first boss fight. By the time you reach the second, you just have too many cards to control it effectively.
If you haven‚Äôt duplicated your target card at the first boss fight, that might be a good time to reset your run.

Games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Farming-Strat.title: Farming Strategy
Games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Farming-Strat.content:
Laboratory 0 
                  
                

A lot of this information may be specific to farming on Laboratory 0. I‚Äôll need to update this if mechanics change in the next event.


Here are a list of some general tips to farming Chaos to build strong decks for your characters.
Chaos Difficulty
The best difficulty to farm is considered to be Difficulty 8, for a few reasons:

Enemy levels increase a lot when moving up to 9
8 with Nightmare mode gives consistent access to Tier 13-14 save data, which is generally enough to fit the decks you want.

Chaos Effects
Some effects are much easier to manage than others. Things like:

Decrease health (take damage) at beginning of each turn
Increase Elite and Boss HP & Damage
Increase number of Elite fights
Decrease max health

are not too bad. Especially for Laboratory 0, the scary monsters who can end your run are actually in normal fights. So choosing Elite fights has a lot of benefits.
The bad effects you want to avoid are:

Enemies gain Morale/Fortify after X turns
Enemies gain Morale/Fortify upon enemy death

because these can create impossible fights that will wipe your run.
Reducing credits is fine if you just want to finish the runs, but if you‚Äôre trying to build a great deck you need a fair amount of credits to remove cards, buy neutral cards, and buy equipment. So events within Chaos that give credits are pretty valuable.
Chaos Upgrades
There is an upgrade in the Chaos system that increases the chance of encountering Rare Species (upgraded versions of normal enemies) by up to 45%. The problem with this is that sometimes the enemies are strong enough to end your run, while the only upside is that you get more Chaos Orbs.
However! If you reset your Chaos Upgrades, all tiers remain unlocked and you can choose which upgrades to enable. And you get all of our Chaos Orbs back.
So just reset, and re-enable everything except for the Rare Species probably up. Profit.

Games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Micro/2025120.content:
Chizuru is interesting, but doesn‚Äôt really add anything new to my lineup since Mei-Lin is already strong single-target.
Obvious synergy is with Rin and Tressa, and I don‚Äôt have either of them built. Shame that Renoa‚Äôs bullet discard doesn‚Äôt trigger Will-o-wisp.
A strong multi-target attacker is probably what I need, and that makes me wonder if I should have just pulled Yuki. But using her in her showcase was kind of underwhelming and I‚Äôm not sold on the character design either.
So I think I need to just resist the FOMO and wait for someone I can really get behind.

Renoa is pretty good now, but it sounds like she is getting pretty significant buffs/fixes.
Up until now, her 3-1 and 7 potentials, which increased the strength of Dirge Bullet, had not been applied to the discard effect.
In addition, the Conqueror‚Äôs Aspect set bonus will also start applying to Dirge Bullet. So that‚Äôs a flat 35% damage increase, as well as a 35% boost to crit damage. Insane!

Tried a Mei-Lin + Mika + Cassius team, and it worked really well. The card draw was a great help in setting up combos and extending them as much as possible. I have a few good +1AP epiphanies on my Draw cards, so I ended up having a lot of AP left over. I may even be able to drop Mika for Veronica if I ever draw her.
My second team remains an unsolved issue, though. I‚Äôm going to stick with Renoa + Nia, so if my third is not Cassius then maybe Rei? Or maybe even move Mika over here.

Posts/transparent-leadership.title: Transparent Leadership
Posts/transparent-leadership.content:
From Transparent Leadership Beats Servant Leadership, by Chris at Entropic Thoughts:

In my book, a good leader
coaches people,
connects people,
[‚Ä¶]
creates direct links between supply and demand (instead of deliberately making themselves a middle man),
[‚Ä¶]
generally makes themselves redundant.

I really related with many of the points in this post. Coincidentally, I had just recently come to some similar conclusions at my own workplace, too.
Effective leaders enable people to solve problems and make progress on their own, so the presence of the best leaders will probably be hard to notice.
I am reminded of a quote from Lao-Tzu (or at least one version of its translation) that has stuck in my mind:

A leader is best when people barely know he exists. When his work is done, his aim fulfilled, they will say: We did it ourselves.

I would often place myself as a middle man in communications deliberately, especially when I was invested in the communication and the other parties involved were also busy doing other things at the same time. The intent was that I could steer the conversation to an efficient consensus, by framing the discussions and paraphrasing or summarizing (what I thought to be) the important points.
In reality though, I was often doing more harm than good.
By placing myself in the middle of communications, I make myself a bottleneck. If I was busy doing something else, I might delay responses, and it was often faster to just have the two people talk to each other directly.
And when I put information through my own filter of what I felt was important or not, It‚Äôs too easy to get the nuance wrong. Even if things seemed to work out at the time, small differences in understanding can compound over time and turn into a bigger problem in the future. In these cases too, I think now that it‚Äôs more effective to just have everyone speak to each other directly.
Of course, not everyone can be talking to everyone else all the time, and determining how much is too much might be an area where my input could help. But in general, I‚Äôm trying very hard not to speak for other people, and am trying instead to be someone who can connect people to each other quickly and efficiently.

Site-Info/Colophon.title: Colophon
Site-Info/Colophon.content:
This site is build with Quartz v4, which is a static-site generator that transforms a folder of Markdown files into a website.
It‚Äôs designed to work well with Obsidian‚Äôs features, and that is what I use to write my content. I‚Äôm not that deep in the Obsidian ecosystem, and I don‚Äôt really use any advanced features, but everything about it, especially PC/Mobile cross-functionality, is pretty good.
Because I access my Obsidian Vault on both desktop and mobile, the vault is saved in a weird location in my iCloud drive:
~/Library/Mobile Documents/iCloud~md~obsidian/Documents/Obsidian/

When building this site with Quartz, I have a script that batch-copies the files from my Obsidian vault into the Quartz folder, which it then uses to generate the site. The generated site is pushed to Github, where I have an Action setup to copy the contents of the public/ folder to my VPS.
I‚Äôve always felt that it‚Äôs unwieldy to install static-site generators on the VPS, so I prefer to do the generation on my local machine and just copy over the outputted files.
Since the Markdown content is synced via iCloud, I can even set up a cron task on my home computer to build + deploy every hour.

Site-Info/Site-todo.title: Site todo
Site-Info/Site-todo.content:
In addition to using this site as a general wiki for my thoughts, I‚Äôm eyeing the possibility of migrating my entire blog to this format. I Currently make my site with Jekyll (a great product!) but I have a lot of customization living in each post‚Äôs frontmatter, and while I do have a variety of convenience scripts set up, I kind of need to be sitting at my desktop machine in order to create and publish posts.
With Quartz, I just add a new file somewhere, slap on a few words, and it‚Äôs already a part of my website. I want to see if there is a way to stay within this dead-simple workflow, and somehow recreate the functionality of my current site.

about.title: About Me
about.content:
My name is Alex. I grew up near Boulder, CO and spent most of my childhood reading books, playing music, and playing video games. I learned programming by making bad games for my TI-83 calculator. The first things I published online were bad flash websites.
In college I studied programming and human-computer interaction. A team of classmates and I made¬†a few apps¬†on Facebook, which eventually turned into a startup. This was the first time I made something that was used by a large number of people. It became my introduction to making real products that have users and make money.
I have been working at a mobile game company in Japan since 2010. Because my day-job doesn‚Äôt currently involve much programming, I like to work on¬†fun projects¬†on the side that let me build things directly.
Part of the reason I maintain this blog is the hope that it will help me make more connections online. Please feel free to¬†get in touch! It would make me very happy.
